1620 IMAGE-HIGH-RES MOLCAA 8528 S1381-1169(12)00297-X 10.1016/j.molcata.2012.09.007 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Catalytic performance over different CZA catalysts before and after the ATD test under the reaction conditions of 230°C, 5MPa, GHSV of 10,000h−1, 1mL catalyst and syngas composition of CO/CO2/H2/N2 (volume ratio)=15:5:70:10. Fig. 2 XRD patterns of the precursors of three representative CZA catalysts. Fig. 3 XRD patterns of four representative calcined CZA catalysts. Fig. 4 XRD patterns of four representative reduced CZA catalysts. Fig. 5 TPR profiles of four representative calcined CZA catalysts. Fig. 6 XPS spectra of Cu(2p) core level region of the four representative reduced CZA catalysts. Fig. 7 Cu-KLL Auger spectrum of the reduced 2T-CZA catalyst. Fig. 8 XRD profiles of 2T-CZA(B) and 2T-CZA(A) catalysts. Fig. 9 HR-TEM photographs of 2T-CZA(B) (a) and 2T-CZA(A) (b) catalysts. Fig. 10 TGA and DTG profiles of 2T-CZA(B) and 2T-CZA(A) catalysts. Surfactant-assisted preparation of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst for methanol synthesis from syngas Zheng Chu a b Haibo Chen b Yang Yu b Qiong Wang b Dingye Fang a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, Engineering Research Center of Large Scale Reactor Engineering and Technology, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, China b Research Institute of Nanjing Chemical Industry Group, Nanjing 210048, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 21 64251002; fax: +86 21 64251002. Graphical abstract Catalytic performance over different CZA catalysts before and after the accelerated thermally induced deactivation (ATD) test under the reaction conditions of 230°C, 5MPa, GHSV of 10,000h −1, 1mL catalyst and syngas composition of CO:CO2:H2:N2 (volume ratio)=15:5:70:10. Highlights ► Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 (CZA) catalyst was prepared by two-step precipitation method. ► The 2T-CZA catalyst showed better catalytic performance. ► Cu0 is main active site in methanol synthesis from syngas over CZA catalyst. ► Smaller crystallite size of Cu and higher Cu specific surface area are favorable. ► The slight drop of catalytic activity is due to the decrease in surface Cu atoms. Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 (CZA) catalysts were prepared by two-step precipitation method with the assistance of the surfactant, tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAH) or polyethylene glycol (PEG), and evaluated in methanol synthesis from syngas. Effects of input amount of the surfactant and accelerated thermally induced deactivation (ATD) on the activity of the catalyst were investigated under the reaction conditions of 230°C, 5MPa, gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 10,000h−1 and the syngas composition of CO/CO2/H2/N2 (volume ratio)=15:5:70:10. Among the catalysts investigated, 2T-CZA catalyst, prepared with addition of 2wt.% TEAH in the course of the coprecipitation of Cu2+ and Zn2+, exhibited better catalytic performance due to its smaller crystallite size of Cu and higher Cu surface area, over which methanol space-time yield (STY) was 1.26 times as heavy as that over blank CZA catalyst, prepared without any surfactant's assistance, and 1.25 times as that over commercially famous CX catalyst for methanol synthesis from syngas in China. Meanwhile, 2T-CZA catalyst showed satisfactory thermal stability, in which methanol STY decreased by only 5.2% because of growing up of crystallite size of Cu and decrease in the number of surface Cu atoms after the ATD test to be conducted in situ at 350°C for 20h in syngas. Keywords Methanol synthesis Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst Surfactant-assisted preparation Thermal stability 1 Introduction With the rapid development of modern industry, the energy and environmental issues have become two major concerns. Methanol is a kind of important chemical feedstock, transportation fuel and clean energy carrier for fuel cells [1]. Therefore, methanol synthesis from syngas has been attracting evergrowing attention. The catalyst was considered unanimously as a key factor in the production of methanol. Methanol synthesis catalyst mainly included Cu-based [2–5] and noble metal catalysts [6–8], in which the former with inexpensive price and high activity has some advantages over the latter. Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 (CZA) catalyst was the methanol synthesis catalyst to be studied extensively and applied largely in industrial production. It was corroborated that the synergism of Cu and ZnO resulted in good activity in methanol synthesis [9,10], and Al2O3 as a promoter not only can prevent agglomeration of active phase but also accelerate the adsorption and activation of CO because of its disorder and defect surface domain [11]. Bahmani et al. [12,13] investigated the effect of metal oxide additives on the properties of CZA catalyst in methanol synthesis from syngas and proposed that Mn and Zr promoted catalysts have high performance. Phan et al. [14] prepared the CZA monoliths and obtained higher activity of monolith in methanol synthesis in terms of fixed bed reactor, which was attributed to the thermal properties of the steel monolith. More efforts were put into improving the preparation method of CZA catalyst. Jensen et al. [15] studied the flame combustion synthesis of CZA catalyst, in which the optimal composition was obtained and the role of individual catalyst components was also discussed. Hu et al. [16,17] prepared nanosize CZA methanol synthesis catalyst by the metal surfactant phase transfer technique and investigated effects of additives, chain length of surfactant and preparation conditions. Liu et al. [1] reported that polyoxyethylene octylphenol, as a surfactant, had promoting effect on Cu/ZnO catalyst for low-temperature methanol synthesis by lowering particle size and increasing Cu specific surface areas. In this work, the assistant effects of two typical surfactants on preparing CZA methanol synthesis catalyst were investigated, respectively, and the activity loss of the catalyst after the ATD test was also studied. The physicochemical properties of catalysts were characterized by XRD, H2-TPR, N2 sorption, N2O chemisorption, HR-TEM, XPS and TG-DTG. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of CZA catalysts CZA catalysts, with the mass ratio of Cu/Zn/Al=70.0%:23.6%:6.4%, were prepared by the two-step precipitation method. The binary matrix containing Cu2+ and Zn2+ was first obtained by adding the mixed nitrates of Cu and Zn dropwise to the given volume of 1molL−1 NaHCO3 aqueous solution with or without the surfactant, tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAH) or polyethylene glycol (PEG), at 75°C until pH was 7.0–7.2. The binary matrix was aged and then washed using deionized water at 75°C until meeting the requirement of diphenylamine sulfate test, indicative of a negligible content of residual Na+ in the binary matrix. The Al2O3 support slurry was prepared by dropwise adding 10wt.% ammonia to Al(NO3)3 aqueous solution at room temperature until pH was about 7.0 and then was poured into the binary matrix under vigorous stirring at 75°C to obtain the precursor of CZA catalyst. The precursor obtained was washed, filtered, dried overnight at 120°C, calcined at 350°C for 2h, pressed and crushed into 16–40mesh. The CZA catalysts prepared with no surfactant, 2wt.% of TEAH and 2wt.% of PEG were marked as blank CZA, 2T-CZA and 2P-CZA, respectively, and other CZA catalysts were marked similarly. A commercially famous methanol synthesis catalyst CX in China, with the same composition as the catalyst prepared in this work, was selected as a reference catalyst. The symbols and main physicochemical properties of the catalysts are listed in Table 1 . 2.2 Activity test of the catalysts Methanol synthesis from syngas over the CZA catalyst was carried out in a continuous flow stainless steel tubular fixed-bed reactor (inside diameter=6mm). 1mL catalyst was loaded in the constant temperature zone of the reactor, and some quartz sand was packed in two ends of the catalyst. The catalyst was first reduced in situ by 1500mLmin−1 5 vol.% H2/N2 at programmed temperature which varied from room temperature to 210°C and was kept at this temperature for 20h. Then the temperature was increased to 230°C and reached stable, the syngas of 10,000h−1, with the composition of CO/CO2/H2/N2 (volume ratio)=15:5:70:10, was fed into the reactor at 5MPa. To investigate the thermal stability of the catalysts in shorter time, the accelerated thermally induced deactivation (ATD) test was universally applied [18,13]. In this work, the ATD test was conducted in the middle of the catalytic performance evaluation at 350°C for 20h under the atmosphere of syngas, after which the reaction conditions of 230°C and 5MPa were recovered again. Not only before the ATD treatment but also after that, the products were analyzed after the reaction for 5h. The products were sampled for 3 times at intervals of 2.5h, and CO conversion and methanol space-time yield (STY) were the averages of 3 results. The CO conversion was obtained online by using Infrared Gas Analyzer with precision of 0.1% of F.S. made in China, and the crude alcohols were collected by ice-bath and analyzed by using Agilent 7890A gas chromatography equipped with FID detector and a HP-Innowax capillary column (60m×0.32mm×0.05μm). 2.3 Characterization of the catalysts The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker AXS D8 Focus diffractometer operated at 40kV, 40mA (Cu Kα radiation, λ =0.15406nm), and the diffraction patterns were taken in the range of 10°<2θ <80°. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) characterization was performed in a U type tubular quarts reactor filled with 50mg catalyst by using a gas mixture 5vol.% H2/N2 as a carrier gas at a flow rate of 40mLmin−1. The heating rate was controlled at 10°Cmin−1. The hydrogen uptake was continuously monitored using a gas chromatography equipped with TCD detector during the reaction. The specific surface area was measured by N2 sorption at −196°C with BET method on a NOVA 4200e surface area and pore size analyzer. The Cu specific surface area of the reduced CZA catalysts was measured by N2O chemisorption at 60°C assuming a molar stoichiometry of Cu:N2O=2 and a surface atomic density of 1.46×1019 Cuatomsm−2 [19]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopies (XPS) of samples were recorded on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 spectrometer (Perkin Elmer, USA) using Al Kα radiation (1486.6eV). The binding energies were calculated with respect to C 1s peak at 285eV with a precision of ±0.2eV. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) was used to observe the size change of metal Cu after the ATD test on a JEM-2100 with an acceleration voltage of 200kV. Thermal gravity analysis (TGA) and differential thermal gravity (DTG) characterizations were carried out on a PerkinElmer Pyris Diamond TG-DTA analyzers, in which the catalyst was heated programmedly from 50°C to 800°C at the rate of 10°Cmin−1 in the atmosphere of air of 100mLmin−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Assay results of the catalysts In Fig. 1 , the activities of the different CZA catalysts are compared in terms of CO conversion in methanol synthesis from syngas. It can be seen that, before the ATD test, the CO conversion (60.7%) over blank CZA catalyst was quite lower than that (65.9%) over CX catalyst. However, as the introduction of the surfactant in preparing the binary matrix, the CO conversion over resultant CZA catalysts increased significantly and was higher than that over CX catalyst, in which CO conversion reached 71.1% over both 5P-CZA and 10T-CZA catalysts. After the ATD test, CO conversion over all CZA catalysts dropped in different extents, in which the CO conversion over 2T-CZA catalyst was the highest to be 67.7% that was even higher than that over CX catalyst before the ATD test. The methanol STYs, during the stability phase of the reaction, over different CZA catalysts before and after ATD test are presented also in Fig. 1. It is clear that the methanol STYs over the CZA catalysts prepared with the assistance of two surfactants are all higher than not only that over blank CZA catalyst (1.066ggcat −1 h−1 before the ATD test and 0.944ggcat −1 h−1 after the test), but also that over CX catalyst (1.072ggcat −1 h−1 before the ATD test and 0.991ggcat −1 h−1 after the test). Among all CZA catalysts investigated, 2T-CZA catalyst showed highest catalytic performance with the methanol STYs of 1.342ggcat −1 h−1 before the ATD test and 1.272ggcat −1 h−1 after the test. 3.2 Characterization of the catalysts 3.2.1 XRD Fig. 2 shows XRD patterns of three representative CZA catalyst precursors (before calcination). As shown in Fig. 2, three crystal phases can be identified in each XRD pattern, in which the characteristic diffraction peaks located at 2θ =11.9°, 14.6°, 17.3°, 18.9°, 24.6° and 29.6° are assigned to (Cu,Zn)2CO3(OH)2 (rosasite phase, PDF# 35-0502), the peaks at 2θ =27.5°, 33.0°, 36.6°, 39.5°, 46.5° and 47.0° to (Cu,Zn)5(CO3)2(OH)6 (aurichalcite phase, PDF# 17-0743) and the peaks at 2θ =31.9°, 36.0°, 41.3°, 56.4° to (Cu)2CO3(OH)2 (malachite, PDF# 02-0806). It is noticed that rosasite is dominant crystal phase in CZA catalyst precursor prepared with the assistance of the surfactants. Many authors reported [10,20–22] that rosasite can be thermally decomposed into Cu x Zn1−x O solid solution which is the main active phase in methanol synthesis. Wang et al. [10] considered that the catalyst precursor with higher diffraction peak intensity at 2θ =17.3° contained more rosasite phases. In Fig. 2, the peak intensity of 2T-CZA catalyst precursor at 2θ =17.3° is the highest in three representative ones, so it can be concluded that more rosasite phases were generated with addition of 2wt.% TEAH in the course of preparing the binary matrix, which can also account for better catalytic performance over 2T-CZA catalyst in methanol synthesis from syngas. Fig. 3 displays XRD patterns of four representative calcined CZA catalysts. The two main characteristic diffraction peaks of CuO (PDF# 65-3411) and three weak but visible characteristic diffraction peaks of ZnO (PDF# 65-2309) can be identified, in which they locate at 2θ =35.7°, 38.9° and 2θ =31.8°, 66.4°, 67.9°, respectively. The characteristic diffraction peak of graphite C (2θ =26.4°, PDF# 01-0646) resulted from the addition of 1.5wt.% additive during catalyst tableting process. Fig. 4 shows XRD patterns of the four reduced CZA catalysts. The characteristic diffraction peaks of ZnO remain, and the characteristic diffraction peaks of CuO disappear however, and the characteristic diffraction peaks of Cu (PDF# 65-9026) appeared at 2θ =43.3°, 50.5° and 74.2°, corresponding to the crystal planes of Cu (111), (200) and (220), respectively. It indicates that CuO was reduced completely by 5vol.% H2/N2 to Cu0 and the state of ZnO did not change, in which Cu0 is the main active site in methanol synthesis from syngas [23–25]. The characteristic diffraction peaks of Al2O3 are not observed in Figs. 3 and 4, which means that Al2O3 existed as the amorphous phase or high dispersion in the catalysts. The crystallite sizes of Cu in the reduced CZA catalysts are determined by Scherrer formula with the full peak width at half maximum height of the characteristic diffraction peak of Cu (111) and listed in Table 1. As shown in Table 1, the crystallite size of Cu in the reduced blank CZA catalyst is higher than that in the reduced CX catalyst. However, with the introduction of the surfactant TEAH or PEG in the course of preparing the binary matrix, the crystallite size of Cu decreased and became smaller than that in the reduced CX catalyst, of which the reduced 2T-CZA catalyst exhibited the smallest crystallite size of Cu. As for CZA methanol synthesis catalyst, smaller crystallite size of Cu is favorable to increase its catalytic performance. 3.2.2 H2-TPR The reducibility of the copper species in the four representative CZA catalysts was characterized by H2-TPR technique. As can be shown in Fig. 5 , each of TPR profiles shows single reduction peak and the reduction temperature at peak maximum varies at 232–257°C from blank CZA to 2T-CZA catalyst. H2-TPR characterization indicates that with the introduction of the surfactant in the course of preparing the binary matrix, the reduction temperature at peak maximum of resultant CZA catalyst shifts to higher temperature. It was reported [10,26] that the shift of the reduction temperature related to the interaction between CuO and ZnO lattices in CZA catalyst, in which the shift to higher reduction temperature in H2-TPR profile implied a stronger interaction between the two lattices. In Fig. 5, the reduction temperature at peak maximum of 2T-CZA catalyst is the highest to be 257°C, meaning that the stronger interaction between CuO and ZnO occurred. 3.2.3 N2 sorption and N2O chemisorption The BET specific surface area (S BET) and the Cu specific surface area (S Cu) over all the CZA catalysts are shown in Table 1. As shown in Table 1, S Cu increases with introduction of the surfactant, and the higher S BET is favorable to increase S Cu. Combining Table 1 with Fig. 2, it is concluded that the higher S Cu over CZA catalyst can promote the catalytic performance of the catalyst in methanol synthesis from syngas, which is in agreement with some observations reported [26,27]. 3.2.4 XPS In order to ascertain further the active site of the CZA catalyst in methanol synthesis from syngas, XPS characterization was carried out, and Cu(2p) XPS spectra of the four representative reduced CZA catalysts are presented in Fig. 6 . In Fig. 6, two main peaks in each XPS spectrum, which locate at binding energy (BE)=932–933eV and BE=952–953eV, should be ascribed to the XPS characteristic peaks of Cu2p3/2 and Cu2p1/2, respectively. In addition, no characteristic satellite peak of Cu2+ at BE of about 945eV appears in each XPS spectrum, which reveals that the Cu2+ was completely reduced to Cu0 or Cu+ under the reduction conditions in this work. Since the BE of Cu0 (932.7eV) and Cu+ (932.4eV) in Cu2p3/2 band are almost the same, they can be assigned according to the different kinetic energy (KE) of Auger Cu-KLL line position in Cu0 (918.6eV) and Cu+ (916.8eV) [28]. Fig. 7 shows Cu-KLL Auger spectrum of the reduced 2T-CZA catalyst. The Auger line position is located at KE=918.2eV, which demonstrates further that the element of Cu exists mainly as Cu0. Accordingly, the active site is speculated mainly to be Cu0 over CZA catalysts in methanol synthesis from syngas. It can be seen that, with the introduction of surfactant in catalyst preparation, the BE of Cu2p3/2 over the reduced CZA catalysts shifts to high value to different extents, of which the reduced 2T-CZA catalyst shows the highest BE of Cu2p3/2, being equal to 933.4eV. The high BE of Cu2p3/2 over the reduced CZA catalyst is beneficial to the adsorption of electron-rich CO over active site of Cu0 [11], and adsorption of the reactants over the catalyst is a precondition for a heterogeneous catalytic reaction. 3.3 Thermal stability of the 2T-CZA catalyst Thermal stability of Cu-based catalyst is a fatal criterion to evaluate its catalytic performance due to the lower Hütting temperature (about 0.3 T m), at which surface atoms become significantly mobile, and lower Tamman temperature (about 0.5 T m) of metal Cu, at which lattices begin to be appreciably mobile, where T m, refer to melting point of metal Cu, is about 1356K. As mentioned in Section 2.2, the ATD test can considerably shorten the investigation time of thermal stability. 2T-CZA catalyst shows better catalytic performance and satisfactory thermal stability in methanol synthesis from syngas, but after the ATD test, the CO conversion and methanol STY all showed still a slight drop. The similar phenomenon was also observed over the CZA catalyst prepared by Wang et al. [10]. To detect the causes of the activity loss, XRD, HR-TEM, TGA and DTG characterizations were implemented. The reduced 2T-CZA catalyst that was used for 10h in methanol synthesis before the ATD test is designated as 2T-CZA(B) and used for 10h after the test as 2T-CZA(A) catalyst. Fig. 8 shows XRD profiles of the 2T-CZA catalyst before and after the ATD test. It is evident that the two characteristic diffraction peaks of Cu in the pattern of 2T-CZA(A) become narrower than the corresponding peaks in the pattern of 2T-CZA(B), by which according to Scherrer formula, it can be inferred that the crystallite size of Cu increased. Further information was acquired by using HR-TEM technique. The images of 2T-CZA(B) and 2T-CZS(A) catalysts are shown in Fig. 9(a) and (b), respectively. It can be observed that the metal Cu with smaller particle, marked by black areas in Fig. 9, is separately dispersed in 2T-CZA(B), but by contrast the interparticle aggregation occurs in 2T-CZA(A), which is indicative of growing up of metal Cu particle after the ATD test and thereby is in good agreement with the inference obtained by XRD analysis. More useful information was obtained by TGA and DTG techniques. As shown in Fig. 10 , an unusual phenomenon is found that weight loss curves of two used 2T-CZA catalysts both rise after a slight drop, which is attributed to removing of adsorbed water, between 50 and 150°C. The increase in mass can be explained as the incorporation of oxygen into the catalyst by the oxidation of Cu0 in air. Additionally, it indicates also that carbon deposition over 2T-CZA catalyst is considerably little during the reaction. DTG curves of 2T-CZA(B) and 2T-CZA(A) catalysts are displayed also in Fig. 10. There exist mainly two peaks, in which the peak at lower temperature should be assigned to the oxidation of surface Cu0, and the other one at higher temperature be assigned to the oxidation of bulk Cu0 in the used 2T-CZA catalyst. The atomic ratio of surface Cu0 to bulk Cu0 is evaluated to be 1.93 in 2T-CZA(B) and 1.15 in 2T-CZA(A), respectively, by calculating the ratio of the corresponding peak area using computer program. The results imply that the quantity of surface Cu0 decreased after the ATD test, which can be explained as the growing up of Cu0 crystal. Thus, it can be concluded that the slight decrease in activity of 2T-CZA catalyst after the ATD test resulted from the decrease in the number of surface Cu atoms which related to growing up of Cu crystal. 4 Conclusion Effects of input amount of two kinds of surfactants, TEAH and PEG, and accelerated thermally induced deactivation on the activity of CZA catalysts, prepared by two-step precipitation method, were investigated in methanol synthesis from syngas. The results show that the addition of the surfactant in the course of preparing the binary matrix of the CZA catalyst can improve catalytic activity significantly, in which 2T-CZA catalyst displayed better catalytic activity and satisfactory thermal stability. Characterizations show that Cu0 is the main active site over CZA catalysts, and smaller crystallite size of Cu and higher Cu specific surface area are favorable to promote its catalytic activity. The precursors of the surfactant-assisted prepared CZA catalysts contained more rosasite phases which can be decomposed to Cu x Zn1−x O solid solution. A strong electronic interaction between Cu and ZnO was induced after the CZA catalyst containing more Cu x Zn1−x O solid solution was reduced by 5vol.% H2/N2, which decreased BE of Cu2p3/2 and therefore made the adsorption of electron-rich CO over CZA catalyst easier. The slight drop of activity over 2T-CZA catalyst after the ATD test should be ascribed to growing up of Cu crystal and decrease in the number of surface Cu atoms. References [1] L. Liu T.S. Zhao Q.X. coredata.dc:description: Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 (CZA) catalysts were prepared by two-step precipitation method with the assistance of the surfactant, tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAH) or polyethylene glycol (PEG), and evaluated in methanol synthesis from syngas. Effects of input amount of the surfactant and accelerated thermally induced deactivation (ATD) on the activity of the catalyst were investigated under the reaction conditions of 230°C, 5MPa, gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 10,000h−1 and the syngas composition of CO/CO2/H2/N2 (volume ratio)=15:5:70:10. Among the catalysts investigated, 2T-CZA catalyst, prepared with addition of 2wt.% TEAH in the course of the coprecipitation of Cu2+ and Zn2+, exhibited better catalytic performance due to its smaller crystallite size of Cu and higher Cu surface area, over which methanol space-time yield (STY) was 1.26 times as heavy as that over blank CZA catalyst, prepared without any surfactant's assistance, and 1.25 times as that over commercially famous CX catalyst for methanol synthesis from syngas in China. Meanwhile, 2T-CZA catalyst showed satisfactory thermal stability, in which methanol STY decreased by only 5.2% because of growing up of crystallite size of Cu and decrease in the number of surface Cu atoms after the ATD test to be conducted in situ at 350°C for 20h in syngas.
coredata.dc:title: Surfactant-assisted preparation of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst for methanol synthesis from syngas
